<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 358, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 220, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 97, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 70, 677, 91]]<|/det|>
Use standard results from the list of formulae (MF19) to show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 94, 677, 133]]<|/det|>
\[\sum_{r = 1}^{n}(6r^{2} + 6r - 5) = a n^{3} + b n^{2} + c n,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 147, 520, 168]]<|/det|>
where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are integers to be determined.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 148, 920, 166]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 551, 186, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 548, 690, 585]]<|/det|>
Use the method of differences to find \(\sum_{r = 1}^{n} \frac{6r^{2} + 6r - 5}{r^{2} + r}\) in terms of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 549, 920, 568]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 94, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 541, 96]]<|/det|>
The equation \(x^{4} - x^{2} + 2x + 5 = 0\) has roots \(\alpha , \beta , \gamma , \delta .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 106, 144, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 895, 127]]<|/det|>
Find a quartic equation whose roots are \(\alpha^2, \beta^2, \gamma^2, \delta^2\) and state the value of \(\alpha^2 + \beta^2 + \gamma^2 + \delta^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 122, 920, 141]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 146, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 73, 455, 102]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\frac{1}{\alpha^2} + \frac{1}{\beta^2} + \frac{1}{\gamma^2} + \frac{1}{\delta^2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 78, 920, 98]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 510, 186, 529]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 510, 438, 532]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\alpha^4 + \beta^4 + \gamma^4 + \delta^4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 510, 920, 529]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 84, 97, 103]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) is given by \(\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} \cos 2\theta & -\sin 2\theta \\ \sin 2\theta & \cos 2\theta \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & k \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\), where \(0 < \theta < \pi\) and \(k\) is a non-zero constant. The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) represents a sequence of two geometrical transformations, one of which is a shear.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 135, 146, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 134, 920, 171]]<|/det|>
Describe fully the other transformation and state the order in which the transformations are applied.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 153, 920, 171]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 184, 917, 203]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 368, 655, 388]]<|/det|>
Write \(\mathbf{M}^{-1}\) as the product of two matrices, neither of which is \(\mathbf{I}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 585, 667, 604]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(k\), the value of \(\tan \theta\) for which \(\mathbf{M} - \mathbf{I}\) is singular.

<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 504, 89]]<|/det|>
Show that the curve with Cartesian equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[487, 100, 588, 120]]<|/det|>
\[x^{2} - y^{2} = a,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 131, 653, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) is a positive constant, has polar equation \(r^2 = a \sec 2\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 131, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 444, 848, 465]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has polar equation \(r^2 = a \sec 2\theta\), where \(a\) is a positive constant, for \(0 \leqslant \theta < \frac{1}{4}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 475, 146, 494]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 475, 635, 494]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\) and state the minimum distance of \(C\) from the pole.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 475, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(a\), the exact value of the area of the region enclosed by \(C\), the initial line, and the half-line \(\theta = \frac{1}{12}\pi\). [You may use any result from the list of formulae (MF19) without proof.] [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 756, 88]]<|/det|>
Find a vector equation of the common perpendicular to the lines \(OC\) and \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 918, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 235, 88]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 457, 146, 475]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 743, 484]]<|/det|>
Sketch the curves with equations \(y = \left|\frac{x^{2} + 2x + 1}{x - 3}\right|\) and \(y^{2} = \frac{x^{2} + 2x + 1}{x - 3}\) on a single diagram,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 476, 920, 495]]<|/det|>
